formulas.name: Sample Variance
formulas.note: Divide by n-1 for sample (Bessel's correction)

formulas.name: Sharpe Ratio
formulas.note: Excess return per unit of total risk

formulas.name: Quantity Theory of Money
formulas.note: Money supply × Velocity = Price level × Real output

formulas.name: Basic EPS
formulas.formula: EPS = (NI - Pref Div) / Wtd Avg Shares

formulas.name: Diluted EPS
formulas.formula: Diluted EPS = (NI - Pref Div + Convertible Interest) / (Shares + Dilutive Securities)

formulas.name: Current Ratio
formulas.formula: Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities

formulas.name: Quick Ratio
formulas.formula: Quick = (Cash + Receivables + ST Investments) / Current Liabilities

formulas.name: DuPont (5-way)
formulas.formula: ROE = Tax Burden × Interest Burden × EBIT Margin × Turnover × Leverage

formulas.name: CFO (Indirect)
formulas.formula: CFO = NI + Non-cash charges ± WC changes

formulas.name: Free Cash Flow to Firm
formulas.formula: FCFF = NI + NCC + Int(1-t) - FCInv - WCInv
formulas.note: Cash available to all capital providers

formulas.name: Justified P/E (Leading)
formulas.note: b = retention ratio, g = b × ROE

formulas.name: Price-to-Book
formulas.formula: P/B = Price / Book Value per Share

formulas.name: Bond Price
formulas.note: PV of coupons + PV of par

formulas.name: YTM
formulas.formula: Rate that equates PV of all CFs to price
formulas.note: Total return if held to maturity

formulas.name: Macaulay Duration
formulas.note: Weighted average time to receive CFs

formulas.name: Price Change (with Convexity)
formulas.note: More accurate for large yield changes

formulas.name: Call Payoff
formulas.note: Right to buy at strike X

formulas.name: Put Payoff
formulas.note: Right to sell at strike X

formulas.name: Net Return to LP
formulas.formula: Net = Gross - Mgmt Fee - Perf Fee

formulas.name: Treynor Ratio
formulas.note: Return per unit of beta risk

connections.title: TVM Connects Everything
connections.desc: Time value of money from Quants is used in bond pricing (FI), stock valuation (Equity), and NPV/IRR analysis (Corporate). Master PV/FV first.

connections.title: Risk and Return Framework
connections.desc: CAPM from Portfolio Management drives equity required return, which feeds into DDM valuations. Duration/convexity is the fixed income analog of beta.

connections.title: Financial Statements → Valuation
connections.desc: FSA provides the inputs (earnings, cash flows, book value) for equity valuation models and corporate capital budgeting decisions.

connections.title: Cost of Capital Chain
connections.desc: CAPM (Portfolio) → Cost of equity (Corporate) → Discount rate for valuation (Equity). WACC connects debt and equity costs.

connections.title: Derivatives & Risk Management
connections.desc: Derivatives are used to hedge portfolio risk (PM) and manage interest rate exposure (FI). Options pricing uses risk-free rate concepts.

connections.title: Statistics Everywhere
connections.desc: Probability, hypothesis testing, and regression from Quants are used in portfolio optimization, factor models, and economic forecasting.

connections.title: Ethics Overlays All
connections.desc: Ethical standards apply to every area: FSA (reporting integrity), Equity (fair recommendations), PM (fiduciary duty), Derivatives (disclosure).

connections.title: Interest Rates Connect Markets
connections.desc: Central bank policy (Econ) drives interest rates → bond prices (FI) → forward/swap pricing (Derivatives). Fisher equation links inflation and rates.

connections.title: Alternative Investments & Portfolio
connections.desc: Alternatives provide diversification benefits (low correlation) studied in PM. IPS constraints affect allocation to illiquid alternatives.

connections.title: DuPont Analysis Bridge
connections.desc: DuPont decomposes ROE (FSA) into profit margin, turnover, leverage. ROE drives sustainable growth rate (Equity) and measures capital efficiency (Corporate).

practiceExam.title: CFA Level I — 180-Question Practice Exam
practiceExam.instructions: This exam covers all 10 subjects weighted approximately by CFA Institute exam weights. 180 questions. Target: 70%+ to pass.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: A CFA charterholder discovers her firm is systematically overcharging clients. She should FIRST:
options: Report to her supervisor or compliance department
questions.explanation: Standard I(A): First report internally to supervisor/compliance. Dissociate from the activity. External reporting or resignation are later steps.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Under the CFA Standards, "fair dealing" means:
options: All clients receive identical recommendations at the same time
Clients are treated fairly, though not necessarily identically
Only institutional clients receive recommendations first
Fair dealing applies only to buy recommendations
questions.explanation: Fair dealing requires equitable treatment of all clients. Different service levels are acceptable if disclosed, but no client should be systematically disadvantaged.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: An analyst's friend who works at a tech company mentions at dinner that "next quarter looks really good." The analyst should:
options: Not trade based on this potentially material nonpublic information
Share the information with her portfolio manager
questions.explanation: Standard II(A): If the information could be material (would affect stock price), it is MNPI and cannot be traded upon until it becomes public.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: The mosaic theory permits analysts to:
options: Combine non-material nonpublic information with public information to form conclusions
Share insider information within their firm
questions.explanation: Mosaic theory allows combining public information with non-material nonpublic information to develop unique investment insights.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: GIPS compliance requires that composites include:
options: All actual, discretionary, fee-paying portfolios managed under a similar strategy
questions.explanation: GIPS prevents cherry-picking by requiring ALL actual, discretionary, fee-paying portfolios to be included in composites.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: A portfolio manager accepts an expensive bottle of wine from a broker. Under the Standards, she must:
options: Disclose the gift to her employer and assess whether it compromises independence
Accept it since it is common practice
questions.explanation: Standard I(B): Gifts may compromise independence and objectivity. Must disclose to employer and evaluate whether acceptance is appropriate.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Standard IV(A) Loyalty to Employer allows a member to:
options: Take client lists when leaving a firm
Prepare to leave while still employed but not solicit clients until after departure
Compete with the employer while still employed
questions.explanation: Members may plan their departure but must not misappropriate trade secrets, client lists, or solicit clients before leaving.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Under GIPS, verification is:
options: Voluntary and applies to the entire firm
questions.explanation: GIPS verification is voluntary but recommended. If performed, it applies to the entire firm, not individual composites.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Priority of transactions under the Standards is:
questions.explanation: Standard VI(B): Client interests come first, then employer, then personal accounts. This prevents front-running.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: A CFA candidate claims to be a "CFA Level II candidate" on her resume. This is:
options: Acceptable if she passed Level I
A violation — correct usage is "Level II candidate in the CFA Program"
Only acceptable if she is currently enrolled
questions.explanation: Standard VII(B): Cannot imply partial designation. Must reference candidacy, not levels passed.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: An investment manager publishes performance results that exclude terminated accounts with poor returns. This violates:
options: Standard III(D) Performance Presentation and GIPS principles
No standards if the accounts were closed
questions.explanation: Excluding poor-performing terminated accounts creates survivorship bias and misrepresents performance, violating Standard III(D).

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: When local laws conflict with the Code and Standards, a member must:
options: Always follow the Code and Standards
questions.explanation: Follow whichever is stricter — local law or the Code and Standards. This ensures the highest ethical standard prevails.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: An analyst copies a chart from a third-party research report into her own report without attribution. This violates:
options: No standard since charts are public
Only if the data is wrong
questions.explanation: Standard I(C): Using another's work without proper attribution constitutes plagiarism, even for charts and graphs.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Soft dollars should be used for:
questions.explanation: Soft dollar commissions should only be used for research and services that directly benefit the clients whose commissions generated them.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: An investment advisor fails to update a client's IPS after the client retires. This most likely violates:
options: Standard I(A) Knowledge of the Law
questions.explanation: Standard III(C): Suitability requires regularly updating the IPS to reflect changes in client circumstances, risk tolerance, and objectives.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Record retention requirements under the Standards suggest maintaining records for at least:
questions.explanation: Standard V(C): Records should be maintained for at least 7 years to support investment analysis and recommendations.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: A supervisor is MOST likely in violation of Standard IV(C) if she:
options: Fails to establish reasonable compliance procedures
questions.explanation: Supervisors must establish and enforce compliance procedures. Failure to do so violates Standard IV(C) even if they did not directly participate in violations.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Referral fees must be disclosed:
options: To the employer but not the client
To clients and prospective clients before entering the relationship
questions.explanation: Standard VI(C): Referral fees must be disclosed to clients and prospective clients so they can evaluate potential bias.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: GIPS requires a minimum of how many years of compliant performance initially?
questions.explanation: Initially present at least 5 years of GIPS-compliant data (or since inception if less than 5 years), then build forward to 10 years.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Which is NOT a component of the CFA Institute Code of Ethics?
options: Place client interests above your own
Promote the integrity of capital markets
questions.explanation: The Code of Ethics never guarantees returns. It focuses on integrity, competence, client interests, and market integrity.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: An analyst uses a complex valuation model she does not fully understand. This most likely violates:
questions.explanation: Standard I(E): Members must maintain competence and should not use tools or models they do not understand.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Market manipulation under Standard II(B) includes:
options: Spreading false information to inflate a stock price
Publishing research with a sell recommendation
questions.explanation: Market manipulation includes spreading false rumors, wash trading, and other actions designed to artificially affect prices.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Standard III(E) Preservation of Confidentiality requires:
options: Keeping all client information confidential indefinitely
Maintaining confidentiality unless disclosure is required by law or the client permits it
Sharing client information only with senior management
questions.explanation: Client information must be kept confidential unless required by law, needed for an investigation, or the client permits disclosure.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Churning — excessive trading to generate commissions — violates:
options: Standard III(A) Loyalty, Prudence, and Care
questions.explanation: Churning directly violates the duty of loyalty, prudence, and care owed to clients. It may also violate other standards.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: A CFA member can claim GIPS compliance for her firm if:
options: The firm applies GIPS standards to all composites firm-wide
The firm plans to comply within 2 years
questions.explanation: GIPS compliance is all or nothing. A firm must apply GIPS standards across the entire firm, not selectively.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: An analyst writes in a report: "This stock WILL return 20% this year." This violates:
questions.explanation: Guaranteeing future returns is a misrepresentation. Analysts should distinguish between facts, opinions, and projections.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Independence and objectivity are MOST threatened by:
options: Accepting issuer-paid travel to visit a company
questions.explanation: Standard I(B): Issuer-paid travel creates pressure to write favorable research. Best practice: firm pays for analyst travel.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: A firm wants to present non-GIPS-compliant historical performance alongside GIPS-compliant data. This is:
options: Allowed if clearly labeled as non-compliant
Only allowed for the first year
questions.explanation: Non-compliant data may be shown if clearly labeled, but it cannot be linked to or presented as GIPS-compliant performance.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: The primary purpose of an IPS (Investment Policy Statement) is to:
options: Document the client's objectives, constraints, and the investment strategy
questions.explanation: The IPS establishes the framework for managing the client's portfolio, including return objectives, risk tolerance, and constraints.

questions.subject: Ethics
questions.question: Under the ethical decision-making framework, "reflect" means:
options: Evaluate the outcome and what could be improved for future decisions
questions.explanation: The reflection step involves evaluating the decision outcome, considering what worked well and what could be improved for future ethical dilemmas.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: An investment of $10,000 at 8% compounded quarterly for 2 years grows to approximately:

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: The EAR for a stated annual rate of 12% compounded monthly is closest to:

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: A dataset has mean 50 and standard deviation 10. The coefficient of variation is:
questions.explanation: CV = σ/μ = 10/50 = 0.20 or 20%. Measures relative dispersion.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: For a 95% confidence interval with a large sample, the z-value is approximately:

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: In hypothesis testing, a Type I error occurs when:
options: Failing to reject a false null hypothesis
The test statistic equals the critical value
The p-value exceeds the significance level
questions.explanation: Type I error (α): rejecting H₀ when it is actually true. Type II error (β): failing to reject H₀ when it is false.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: The present value of an ordinary annuity of $1,000 for 5 years at 6% is closest to:

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: A positively skewed distribution has:
questions.explanation: Positive skew: tail to the right. Mode < Median < Mean. The mean is pulled toward the tail.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: Bayes' formula is used to:
questions.explanation: Bayes' formula updates prior probabilities using new information to calculate posterior probabilities: P(A|B) = P(B|A)P(A)/P(B).

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: The correlation coefficient ranges from:
questions.explanation: Correlation (ρ) is standardized covariance ranging from -1 (perfect negative) to +1 (perfect positive). 0 = no linear relationship.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: In a simple linear regression, R² = 0.81 means:
options: 81% of the variation in Y is explained by X
81% of observations fall on the line
questions.explanation: R² (coefficient of determination) = proportion of variation in the dependent variable explained by the independent variable.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: The geometric mean return is MOST appropriate for:
options: Measuring compound growth over multiple periods
questions.explanation: The geometric mean accurately reflects compound growth over time. It is always ≤ the arithmetic mean.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: A 99% confidence interval is _____ a 95% confidence interval.
questions.explanation: Higher confidence requires a wider interval. 99% CI uses z=2.58 vs 1.96 for 95%, resulting in a wider range.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: Kurtosis measures:
options: The degree of peakedness and tail weight
questions.explanation: Kurtosis measures tail weight and peakedness. Leptokurtic (>3): fat tails. Platykurtic (<3): thin tails. Mesokurtic (=3): normal.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: A Monte Carlo simulation is used to:
options: Generate random scenarios to model uncertainty and estimate outcomes
questions.explanation: Monte Carlo simulation uses random sampling to model uncertainty, generating thousands of scenarios to estimate probability distributions of outcomes.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market, firms in long-run equilibrium earn:
questions.explanation: Free entry/exit drives economic profit to zero in the long run. Firms earn only normal (accounting) profits.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: If MPC = 0.8, the fiscal multiplier is:

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: A recession is characterized by:
options: Declining real GDP, rising unemployment, falling consumer spending
questions.explanation: Recessions feature declining output, rising unemployment, reduced consumer spending, and often falling inflation.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: Expansionary monetary policy by a central bank involves:
options: Lowering interest rates and/or buying securities
questions.explanation: Expansionary monetary policy: lower interest rates, buy securities (increase money supply), lower reserve requirements.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: According to the quantity theory of money (MV = PY), if M increases and V and Y are constant:
questions.explanation: If V and Y are constant, an increase in M leads to a proportional increase in P (price level) — inflation.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: A country has a comparative advantage in producing a good if:
options: It can produce more of the good than another country
It can produce the good at a lower opportunity cost
questions.explanation: Comparative advantage is based on lower OPPORTUNITY COST, not absolute productivity. Both countries benefit from trade.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: If the nominal interest rate is 8% and inflation is 3%, the real interest rate is approximately:
questions.explanation: Fisher: Real ≈ Nominal - Inflation = 8% - 3% = 5%. Exact: (1.08/1.03) - 1 = 4.85%.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: A monopolist maximizes profit where:
questions.explanation: All firms maximize profit where MR = MC. For monopolists, P > MR because they face a downward-sloping demand curve.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: An increase in a country's current account deficit must be offset by:
options: A decrease in the financial account
An increase in the capital/financial account surplus
questions.explanation: Balance of payments: Current Account + Capital/Financial Account = 0. A current account deficit requires a financial account surplus (capital inflows).

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: Demand is elastic when:
questions.explanation: Elastic demand: |E| > 1. A 1% price change causes more than 1% quantity change. Total revenue falls when price rises.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: The natural rate of unemployment includes:
questions.explanation: Natural rate = frictional + structural unemployment. It excludes cyclical unemployment and represents the economy at full employment.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: A depreciating domestic currency makes:
options: Imports cheaper and exports more expensive
Imports more expensive and exports cheaper (more competitive)
Both imports and exports more expensive
questions.explanation: A weaker domestic currency makes imports more expensive and exports cheaper for foreign buyers, improving competitiveness.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: Under interest rate parity, if domestic rates are higher than foreign rates, the forward exchange rate will show the domestic currency at a:
questions.explanation: Higher domestic rates → domestic currency trades at a forward DISCOUNT. The forward rate offsets the interest rate differential.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: An oligopoly is characterized by:
options: A few large firms with interdependent pricing
questions.explanation: Oligopoly: few large firms, barriers to entry, interdependent decision-making. Examples: airlines, telecom.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Under IFRS, the conceptual framework's fundamental qualitative characteristics are:
questions.explanation: Fundamental: Relevance and Faithful Representation. Enhancing: Comparability, Verifiability, Timeliness, Understandability.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Revenue is recognized when:
questions.explanation: ASC 606/IFRS 15: Revenue recognized when performance obligations are satisfied (goods/services transferred to customer).

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: In periods of rising prices, FIFO compared to LIFO results in:
options: Higher COGS and higher net income
Lower COGS and higher net income
Lower COGS and lower net income
questions.explanation: Rising prices + FIFO: older, cheaper costs in COGS → lower COGS, higher gross profit, higher ending inventory, higher net income.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: DuPont ROE (3-way) decomposes into:
options: Profit margin × Asset turnover × Financial leverage
Revenue growth × Margin expansion × Share buybacks
questions.explanation: ROE = (NI/Revenue) × (Revenue/Assets) × (Assets/Equity) = Profit Margin × Asset Turnover × Financial Leverage.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Operating cash flow using the indirect method starts with:
questions.explanation: Indirect method: Start with net income, add back non-cash charges (depreciation), adjust for working capital changes.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Capitalizing vs. expensing a cost: capitalizing results in:
options: Higher current period expense and lower assets
Higher total assets and higher current period net income
questions.explanation: Capitalizing: asset recorded on balance sheet (higher assets), expense spread over time (higher current net income, lower future NI).

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: A deferred tax liability arises when:
questions.explanation: DTL: taxable income < accounting income now (tax expense > taxes payable). The firm will pay MORE tax in the future.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: The quick ratio excludes _____ from current assets:
questions.explanation: Quick ratio = (Cash + ST Investments + Receivables) / Current Liabilities. Excludes inventory (less liquid) and prepaids.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Depreciation method that produces highest expense in early years:
questions.explanation: Accelerated methods (DDB, SYD) front-load depreciation expense. DDB is most common accelerated method.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Under IFRS, investment property can be reported at:
options: Either cost model or fair value model
questions.explanation: IFRS allows either cost or fair value model for investment property. US GAAP requires cost model only.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Free cash flow to the firm (FCFF) equals:
questions.explanation: FCFF = NI + Non-cash charges + Interest(1-t) - Fixed capital investment - Working capital investment.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: An operating lease vs. finance lease: the operating lease results in:
questions.explanation: Historically, operating leases were off-balance-sheet, resulting in lower reported assets and liabilities. Post-ASC 842/IFRS 16, most leases are capitalized.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Goodwill on the balance sheet arises from:
options: Acquisition price exceeding fair value of net identifiable assets acquired
questions.explanation: Goodwill = Purchase price - Fair value of net identifiable assets acquired. Only from business combinations, never internally generated.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Diluted EPS will be _____ basic EPS:
questions.explanation: Diluted EPS ≤ Basic EPS because it includes the effect of all dilutive securities (options, convertibles) in the denominator.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: The cash conversion cycle equals:
questions.explanation: CCC = Days Inventory Outstanding + Days Sales Outstanding - Days Payable Outstanding. Lower CCC = more efficient.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Under LIFO liquidation in rising prices, a company that draws down old inventory will report:
options: Lower COGS and higher profits than normal
questions.explanation: LIFO liquidation: old, lower-cost inventory enters COGS → lower COGS → higher gross profit. This is a one-time distortion.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: An impairment loss on a long-lived asset is recognized when:
questions.explanation: Impairment: carrying value > recoverable amount (higher of fair value less costs to sell and value in use under IFRS).

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Interest paid is classified as _____ under IFRS and _____ under US GAAP:
options: CFO or CFF under IFRS; CFO under US GAAP
CFI under IFRS; CFF under US GAAP
questions.explanation: IFRS: Interest paid can be CFO or CFF (choice). US GAAP: Interest paid must be classified as CFO.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: The interest coverage ratio is calculated as:
questions.explanation: Interest coverage = EBIT / Interest expense. Measures ability to cover interest payments from operating earnings.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: A company with inventory turnover of 12 has average days in inventory of:
questions.explanation: Days in inventory = 365 / Inventory Turnover = 365 / 12 = 30.4 days.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Comprehensive income includes:
options: Net income plus other comprehensive income (OCI)
questions.explanation: Comprehensive income = Net income + OCI. OCI includes unrealized gains/losses on AFS securities, foreign currency translation, pension adjustments.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Accounts receivable turnover of 8 implies an average collection period of:
questions.explanation: Average collection period = 365 / AR Turnover = 365 / 8 = 45.6 days.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: A project with NPV = +$500,000 should be:
options: Accepted because positive NPV adds shareholder value
Accepted only if IRR exceeds WACC by 5%
questions.explanation: Positive NPV projects add value to the firm. Accept all projects with NPV > 0 (at the appropriate discount rate).

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: WACC is calculated as:
options: Cost of debt + Cost of equity
questions.explanation: WACC = weight of debt × after-tax cost of debt + weight of equity × cost of equity. Uses market value weights.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: The pecking order theory suggests firms prefer financing in this order:
options: Equity, then debt, then internal funds
Internal funds, then debt, then equity
Debt, then equity, then internal funds
questions.explanation: Pecking order: 1) Internal funds (retained earnings), 2) Debt, 3) Equity issuance. Based on information asymmetry.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: Operating leverage is HIGH when a firm has:
options: High variable costs relative to fixed costs
High fixed costs relative to variable costs
questions.explanation: High operating leverage = high fixed costs relative to variable costs. Small revenue changes cause large swings in operating income.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: The IRR is the discount rate at which:
questions.explanation: IRR is the rate that makes NPV = 0. Accept if IRR > required rate of return (cost of capital).

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: A weakness of the payback period method is:
options: It considers the time value of money
It ignores cash flows after the payback period
It is too complex to calculate
It always gives the same result as NPV
questions.explanation: Payback ignores: TVM, cash flows after payback, and risk. It only measures liquidity/time to recover investment.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: Modigliani-Miller (no taxes) states that capital structure:
questions.explanation: MM Proposition I (no taxes): Firm value is independent of capital structure. With taxes, debt adds value through tax shields.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: A company's breakeven quantity is 1,000 units. If fixed costs are $50,000 and variable cost per unit is $30, the price per unit is:

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: Agency costs arise from conflicts between:
options: Shareholders and managers, or shareholders and bondholders
questions.explanation: Agency problems: managers may not act in shareholders' best interest; shareholders may take risks that harm bondholders.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: The cost of equity using CAPM with Rf=3%, β=1.2, market premium=7% is:

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: Working capital management focuses on:
options: Managing current assets and current liabilities efficiently
questions.explanation: Working capital management optimizes current assets (cash, receivables, inventory) and current liabilities (payables) for liquidity and efficiency.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: A company with DOL=3 and DFL=2 has DTL of:
questions.explanation: DTL = DOL × DFL = 3 × 2 = 6. A 1% change in revenue leads to a 6% change in EPS.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: Stakeholder theory vs shareholder theory: stakeholder theory considers:
options: The interests of all stakeholders: employees, customers, suppliers, community
questions.explanation: Stakeholder theory considers all parties affected by corporate decisions, not just shareholders.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: The profitability index (PI) is calculated as:
options: PV of future CFs / Initial Investment
questions.explanation: PI = PV of future cash flows / Initial Investment. Accept if PI > 1.0. Useful for capital rationing.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: Using the Gordon Growth Model: D₁=$2, r=10%, g=4%. Stock value is:

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: The semi-strong form of market efficiency implies:
options: No analysis can generate excess returns
Fundamental analysis cannot generate excess returns because all public information is reflected in prices
Only insider information is reflected in prices
questions.explanation: Semi-strong: all public information reflected in prices. Fundamental analysis (using public info) cannot generate abnormal returns.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: A price-weighted index is most affected by:
questions.explanation: Price-weighted index (e.g., DJIA): highest-priced stock has the most influence, regardless of company size.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: A stock with P/E of 15 and expected earnings growth of 10% has a PEG ratio of:
questions.explanation: PEG = P/E / Growth rate = 15/10 = 1.5. PEG > 1 may suggest overvaluation relative to growth.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: The sustainable growth rate equals:
questions.explanation: g = ROE × b, where b = retention ratio = 1 - dividend payout ratio.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: Enterprise value (EV) equals:
questions.explanation: EV = Market cap + Total debt - Cash. Represents the total value of the business to all capital providers.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: A value-weighted index gives the most weight to:
options: The company with the largest market capitalization
questions.explanation: Market-cap weighted indexes (e.g., S&P 500) give more weight to larger companies by market capitalization.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: If a stock's intrinsic value > market price, the stock is:
questions.explanation: If intrinsic value exceeds market price, the stock is trading below its estimated worth — undervalued. Consider buying.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: Preferred stock is similar to debt because:
options: It pays fixed dividends and has priority over common stock in liquidation
questions.explanation: Preferred stock has fixed dividends (like coupon), priority in liquidation, but typically no voting rights. It is a hybrid security.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: The weak form of market efficiency suggests that:
options: Technical analysis cannot generate abnormal returns
Fundamental analysis cannot generate abnormal returns
questions.explanation: Weak form: historical price/volume data fully reflected in prices. Technical analysis (using past prices) cannot generate abnormal returns.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: A stock has ROE=15%, payout ratio=40%. Sustainable growth rate is:

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: Price-to-book ratio is LEAST useful for valuing:
options: Technology companies with mostly intangible assets
questions.explanation: P/B is less useful for companies with significant intangible assets (tech, pharma) since book value understates their true asset base.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: In a limit order to buy at $50:
options: The order executes at $50 or higher
The order executes at $50 or lower
The order executes immediately at market price
questions.explanation: Buy limit order: maximum price you're willing to pay. Executes at $50 or below.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: The dividend discount model assumes stock value equals:
options: Total of all past dividends paid
Present value of all expected future dividends
Next year's dividend divided by the stock price
questions.explanation: DDM: stock value = PV of all expected future dividends. The Gordon Growth Model is a special case with constant growth.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: A stock index rebalancing creates:
options: Temporary price pressure from index fund trades
questions.explanation: Index rebalancing forces index funds to buy additions and sell deletions, creating temporary demand/supply imbalances and price pressure.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: EV/EBITDA is preferred over P/E when comparing firms because:
options: It is unaffected by differences in capital structure, depreciation, and tax rates
questions.explanation: EV/EBITDA neutralizes differences in leverage, depreciation methods, and tax jurisdictions, enabling better cross-company comparison.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A bond is trading at a premium when:
questions.explanation: Premium: coupon rate > YTM → price > par. Discount: coupon rate < YTM → price < par.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Macaulay duration for a zero-coupon bond equals:
questions.explanation: Zero-coupon bond: only one cash flow at maturity. Macaulay duration = time to maturity exactly.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Convexity is beneficial to bondholders because:
options: Price rises more when yields fall than it drops when yields rise by the same amount
questions.explanation: Positive convexity: price-yield relationship is curved. Bond gains more from yield decreases than it loses from equal yield increases.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A callable bond's yield is typically _____ a comparable non-callable bond:
questions.explanation: Callable bonds offer higher yields to compensate investors for call risk (issuer may redeem early when rates fall).

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Credit spread is the difference between:
options: A corporate bond yield and a comparable government bond yield
questions.explanation: Credit spread = Corporate bond YTM - Risk-free benchmark YTM. Compensation for default risk.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: If interest rates rise by 1%, a bond with modified duration of 6 will change in price by approximately:
questions.explanation: ΔP/P ≈ -ModDur × Δy = -6 × 0.01 = -6%. Duration gives the approximate percentage price change.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A putable bond gives the _____ the right to:
options: Bondholder; sell the bond back to the issuer at a specified price
questions.explanation: Putable bond: bondholder can sell (put) the bond back to the issuer at par on specified dates. Protects against rising rates.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: The spot rate curve is also known as the:
questions.explanation: The spot rate curve = zero-coupon yield curve. Each rate applies to a single payment at a specific maturity.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A bond's price and yield have a _____ relationship:
questions.explanation: Bond prices and yields move inversely. When yields rise, present value of future cash flows falls, so bond price drops.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Expected loss from credit risk equals:
questions.explanation: Expected Loss = Probability of Default × Loss Given Default × Exposure at Default.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: An amortizing bond pays:
options: Interest only with principal at maturity
Both principal and interest over the bond's life
questions.explanation: Amortizing bonds repay principal gradually over the life of the bond along with interest, unlike bullet bonds.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: If the yield curve is upward-sloping, the forward rate for a future period is:
options: Lower than the spot rate for that maturity
Higher than the spot rate for that maturity
questions.explanation: Upward-sloping yield curve implies forward rates are higher than current spot rates for corresponding periods.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A floating-rate note (FRN) has minimal _____ risk:
questions.explanation: FRNs reset coupon periodically to market rates, so price stays near par. Minimal interest rate (duration) risk, but credit risk remains.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Investment-grade bonds are rated at least:
questions.explanation: Investment grade: BBB- (S&P/Fitch) or Baa3 (Moody's) and above. Below = high yield/speculative/junk.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A sinking fund provision requires the issuer to:
options: Buy back bonds at a premium
Retire a portion of the bond issue before maturity
questions.explanation: Sinking fund: issuer must retire a specified portion of bonds periodically, reducing credit risk but creating reinvestment risk for holders.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Effective duration is most appropriate for:
questions.explanation: Effective duration accounts for how embedded options (calls, puts) affect cash flows when yields change. Modified duration assumes fixed cash flows.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: If recovery rate is 40%, loss given default (LGD) is:
questions.explanation: LGD = 1 - Recovery Rate = 1 - 0.40 = 60%. If a bond defaults, the investor loses 60% of exposure.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: The price of a bond with a 5% coupon, $1,000 par, 3 years to maturity, and YTM of 5% is:
questions.explanation: When coupon rate = YTM, the bond trades at par ($1,000). Premium: coupon > YTM. Discount: coupon < YTM.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: Duration is measured in units of:
questions.explanation: Duration is measured in years — it represents the weighted average time to receive cash flows (Macaulay) or price sensitivity (Modified).

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A bond covenent is:
options: A government regulation on bond trading
A contractual provision protecting bondholder interests
questions.explanation: Covenants are contractual restrictions. Affirmative: things issuer must do. Negative: things issuer cannot do (e.g., limit additional debt).

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: The reinvestment risk for a bond is highest when:
options: The bond has a short maturity
questions.explanation: Reinvestment risk: coupon payments reinvested at lower rates when rates fall. Zero-coupon bonds have NO reinvestment risk.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: An inverted yield curve suggests:
questions.explanation: An inverted yield curve (short rates > long rates) has historically been a leading indicator of economic recession.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: A forward contract differs from a futures contract because forwards are:
options: OTC, customized, and carry counterparty risk
questions.explanation: Forwards: OTC, customizable, counterparty risk. Futures: exchange-traded, standardized, daily mark-to-market, clearinghouse guaranteed.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: The maximum loss for a buyer of a put option is:
options: The strike price minus the premium
questions.explanation: Option buyer's max loss = premium paid. If the put expires worthless (stock price > strike), the buyer loses only the premium.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: Put-call parity states that:
questions.explanation: Put-call parity: c + PV(X) = p + S. Fiduciary call = Protective put. Holds for European options on same underlying.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: A swap is best described as:
questions.explanation: A swap is equivalent to a series of forward contracts, exchanging cash flows at predetermined intervals.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: The no-arbitrage forward price for a stock at $100 with risk-free rate 6% for 1 year is:
questions.explanation: F = S × (1+r)^T = $100 × 1.06 = $106. If no dividends, the forward price reflects the cost of carry.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: An option is "in the money" when:
options: The option has positive intrinsic value
The option has only time value
The option is at the strike price
questions.explanation: In-the-money: positive intrinsic value. Call: S > X. Put: X > S. Out-of-money: zero intrinsic value.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: In the binomial option pricing model, risk-neutral probabilities are used to:
options: Allow discounting at the risk-free rate to find the no-arbitrage price
questions.explanation: Risk-neutral pricing: use risk-neutral probabilities (not actual) and discount at risk-free rate to get the correct no-arbitrage option price.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: A covered call strategy involves:
options: Buying a call and buying stock
Owning the underlying stock and selling a call option
Buying a put and selling a call
Selling stock and selling a call
questions.explanation: Covered call: long stock + short call. Generates premium income but caps upside. Used when moderately bullish.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: Convenience yield applies to:
options: Physical commodities that provide benefits from holding
questions.explanation: Convenience yield: benefit of holding a physical commodity (e.g., oil for a refinery). Reduces the forward price.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: A protective put involves:
options: Buying a stock and buying a put option on it
Selling a stock and buying a call
questions.explanation: Protective put: long stock + long put. Limits downside to (strike - stock purchase price - premium) while keeping upside.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: The writer of a call option has:
options: Limited potential loss equal to the premium
The right but not the obligation to sell
questions.explanation: Call writer (seller) has theoretically unlimited loss because the stock price can rise indefinitely. Premium received is the maximum gain.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: The J-curve in private equity refers to:
options: Negative returns in early years followed by positive returns later
The shape of the normal distribution
questions.explanation: J-curve: early years show negative returns (fees, investments, write-downs) before investments mature and generate positive returns.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: Property value using the income approach: NOI=$300,000, Cap rate=6%. Value is:

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: A high-water mark provision ensures that:
options: GPs earn performance fees only on profits above the highest previous NAV
LPs can withdraw at any time
questions.explanation: High-water mark: GP earns incentive fees only on NEW profits above the previous peak NAV, preventing double-dipping.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: REITs must distribute at least _____ of income to maintain tax-exempt status:
questions.explanation: REITs must distribute 90%+ of taxable income as dividends. This provides liquid, income-focused real estate exposure.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: Survivorship bias in hedge fund databases causes:
questions.explanation: Failed/closed funds drop from databases, leaving only survivors. Average reported returns are inflated upward.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: An LBO target ideally has:
options: Stable cash flows and undervalued assets
questions.explanation: LBOs use heavy debt, so stable cash flows to service debt are critical. Undervalued assets provide potential upside.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: Infrastructure investments typically offer:
options: High volatility and high short-term returns
Stable, long-duration cash flows with inflation protection
questions.explanation: Infrastructure: essential services (utilities, transport), regulated returns, long-lived assets, often with inflation-linked revenue.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: In a fund-of-funds structure, an additional layer of fees results in:
options: Lower net returns due to double fee layers
questions.explanation: Fund-of-funds charge fees on top of underlying fund fees (fees on fees), reducing net returns to investors.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: Mezzanine financing is:
options: Subordinated debt that ranks between senior debt and equity
questions.explanation: Mezzanine: subordinated debt, higher risk than senior debt but lower risk than equity. Often includes equity warrants/conversion features.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: Hedge fund lock-up periods:
options: Allow investors to withdraw at any time
Prevent investor withdrawals for a specified period
questions.explanation: Lock-up periods (typically 1-2 years) restrict investor redemptions, giving managers time to implement less liquid strategies.

questions.subject: Alternative Investments
questions.question: A lower cap rate implies:
options: Higher property value and/or lower risk
questions.explanation: Value = NOI/Cap Rate. Lower cap rate → higher value. Lower cap rates reflect lower risk or higher growth expectations.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: According to CAPM, the expected return of a stock with β=1.5, Rf=3%, market premium=6% is:

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: The Sharpe ratio measures:
options: Return per unit of systematic risk
Return per unit of total risk (standard deviation)
questions.explanation: Sharpe = (Rp - Rf) / σp. It measures excess return per unit of TOTAL risk (standard deviation), not just systematic.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Diversification reduces _____ risk but not _____ risk:
questions.explanation: Diversification eliminates unsystematic (firm-specific) risk. Systematic (market) risk cannot be diversified away.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: A risk-averse investor has risk aversion coefficient A that is:
questions.explanation: In U = E(R) - ½Aσ², A > 0 for risk-averse (requires compensation for risk), A = 0 for risk-neutral, A < 0 for risk-seeking.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: The minimum variance portfolio:
options: Has the highest expected return on the efficient frontier
Has the lowest possible risk among all portfolios of risky assets
questions.explanation: The minimum variance portfolio has the lowest standard deviation of all possible portfolios. It's the left-most point on the efficient frontier.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Jensen's alpha = +2% means:
options: The portfolio returned 2% less than CAPM predicted
The portfolio returned 2% more than CAPM predicted
questions.explanation: α = actual return - CAPM expected return. Positive alpha = outperformance after adjusting for systematic risk.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: The CML differs from the SML in that the CML:
options: Uses total risk (σ) on the x-axis and only applies to efficient portfolios
Applies to all assets and portfolios
questions.explanation: CML: total risk (σ) on x-axis, only efficient portfolios. SML: beta on x-axis, applies to ALL assets and portfolios.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Two-fund separation theorem states:
options: All investors hold the same optimal risky portfolio, differing only in allocation to the risk-free asset
Two assets are sufficient for diversification
Investors should hold two mutual funds
questions.explanation: Two-fund separation: all investors hold the same tangent (optimal risky) portfolio and adjust risk by mixing with the risk-free asset.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Strategic asset allocation determines approximately _____ of portfolio return variation:
questions.explanation: Research shows strategic asset allocation explains approximately 90% of portfolio return variation over time. Security selection plays a minor role.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: The Treynor ratio is most appropriate for evaluating:
options: A well-diversified portfolio that is part of a larger diversified portfolio
questions.explanation: Treynor uses beta (systematic risk only). Appropriate when the portfolio is part of a larger diversified portfolio where unsystematic risk is eliminated.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: An IPS constraint "LTTLU" stands for:
options: Liquidity, Time horizon, Tax, Legal, Unique circumstances
questions.explanation: IPS constraints: Liquidity needs, Time horizon, Tax considerations, Legal/regulatory, Unique circumstances.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: A stock above the SML is:
questions.explanation: Above SML: expected return > required return for its beta. The stock offers MORE return than needed, so it's undervalued.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Utility: E(R)=10%, σ=15%, A=4. U =:

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Beta of the market portfolio is:
questions.explanation: By definition, the market portfolio has β = 1. β > 1: more volatile than market (aggressive). β < 1: less volatile (defensive).

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: Loss aversion means investors:
options: Feel the pain of losses more intensely than the pleasure of equivalent gains
questions.explanation: Loss aversion (Kahneman & Tversky): the disutility of a loss ≈ 2× the utility of an equivalent gain. Leads to holding losers, selling winners.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: If correlation between two assets is -1, a portfolio of the two can achieve:
questions.explanation: Perfect negative correlation (ρ = -1) allows constructing a zero-risk (risk-free) portfolio through appropriate weighting.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: The slope of the Capital Allocation Line (CAL) equals:
options: The Sharpe ratio of the optimal risky portfolio
questions.explanation: CAL slope = [E(Rp) - Rf] / σp = Sharpe ratio of the risky portfolio. Steeper CAL = better risk-return tradeoff.

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: M-squared (M²) adjusts for risk by:
options: Using beta as the risk measure
Leveraging/deleveraging the portfolio to match market risk, then comparing returns
questions.explanation: M² adjusts portfolio to match market σ, then compares return. M² = (Sharpe_p - Sharpe_m) × σ_m. Positive M² = outperformance.

questions.subject: Quantitative Methods
questions.question: The power of a test equals:
questions.explanation: Power = 1 - β = probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis. Higher power is better.

questions.subject: Economics
questions.question: Stagflation is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Stagflation: high inflation + low/negative economic growth + high unemployment. Very difficult for policymakers.

questions.subject: FSA
questions.question: Under the weighted average cost method for inventory:
options: Most recent costs are in COGS
Average cost of all inventory is used for COGS and ending inventory
questions.explanation: Weighted average: total cost / total units = average cost per unit. Applied to both COGS and ending inventory.

questions.subject: Corporate Issuers
questions.question: The trade-off theory of capital structure balances:
options: Tax benefits of debt against costs of financial distress
questions.explanation: Trade-off theory: optimal capital structure balances tax shield benefits of debt against bankruptcy/financial distress costs.

questions.subject: Fixed Income
questions.question: A bond with higher duration has:
options: Less price sensitivity to yield changes
Greater price sensitivity to yield changes
questions.explanation: Higher duration = greater price sensitivity to interest rate changes. Duration is the primary measure of interest rate risk.

questions.subject: Equity
questions.question: The strong form of market efficiency states that:
options: Only public information is reflected in prices
All information, including private insider information, is reflected in prices
questions.explanation: Strong form: ALL information (public + private/insider) is reflected in prices. Even insider trading cannot generate abnormal returns.

questions.subject: Derivatives
questions.question: The maximum gain for a seller (writer) of a put option is:
questions.explanation: Put writer's maximum gain = premium received (if put expires worthless). Maximum loss = strike price - premium (if stock goes to zero).

questions.subject: Portfolio Management
questions.question: An investor's risk tolerance is typically _____ related to time horizon:
questions.explanation: Longer time horizon → higher risk tolerance. More time to recover from losses, benefit from equity risk premium.
